items.content_html: During lunch, I nipped out to the Post Office to send some parcels when I saw a yellow truck go past with some writing on the side that readâ€”Shawfield: London, Paris, New York, but mainly Stockport! I was just about quick enough to grab a shot.
items.content_text: During lunch, I nipped out to the Post Office to send some parcels when I saw a yellow truck go past with some writing on the side that readâ€”Shawfield: London, Paris, New York, but mainly Stockport! I was just about quick enough to grab a shot.

items.content_html:
The Tour of Britain started today with the first stage route taking in Chorley Road, Swinton, near to where I live. I had every intention of watching from the sidelines, but what with the best weather in ages, the neighboursâ€™ kids round playing in our garden, and getting lost in DIY jobsâ€”bush pruning and insulating the shed â€”it passed me by. I even missed first half an hour of Arsenal vs. United.

The afternoon was soured by news of David Watkinsâ€™ passing.
items.content_text:
The Tour of Britain started today with the first stage route taking in Chorley Road, Swinton, near to where I live. I had every intention of watching from the sidelines, but what with the best weather in ages, the neighboursâ€™ kids round playing in our garden, and getting lost in DIY jobsâ€”bush pruning and insulating the shed â€”it passed me by. I even missed first half an hour of Arsenal vs. United. 

![](https://notes.gazshaw.co.uk/uploads/2023/3bb86854-35e6-4ebe-9175-1445f10bba3c.jpeg)

![](https://notes.gazshaw.co.uk/uploads/2023/6e940872-ef9e-492b-9d6b-2cd588d44977.jpeg)

The afternoon was soured by news of David Watkinsâ€™ passing.

items.content_html: Itâ€™s National Cinema Day, so weâ€™re off out to see Elemental.
items.content_text: Itâ€™s National Cinema Day, so weâ€™re off out to see *Elemental*.

items.content_html:
I was already peeved at missing the Wigan day out due to the train strike, but Salford also lost quite convincingly. It could have been worse scorewise and little changes from last week re: making the playoffs: need to beat Warrington at home next week, defeat Hull KR away the week after, and do Catalans in the last game. Though the way the results went tonight, Catalans may not have the luxury to field a weakened game against us.

Elsewhere, Leigh vs. Huddersfield was abandoned in the second half due to floodlight failure. Only the third game to be abandoned before the 60 minutes threshold in the summer era.
items.content_text:

It could have been worse scorewise and little changes from last week re: making the playoffs: need to beat Warrington at home next week, defeat Hull KR away the week after, and do Catalans in the last game. Though the way the results went tonight, Catalans may not have the luxury to field a weakened game against us.

Elsewhere, Leigh vs. Huddersfield was abandoned in the second half due to floodlight failure. Only the third game to be abandoned before the 60 minutes threshold in the summer era.

items.title: Hatch, Manchester
items.content_html:
Earlier this week I came across a modernist illustration by Bo Lundberg of Hatch with the Mancunian Way in the background. A shipping container-style market of independent eateries, coffee shops, bars, breweries, clothes shops, florists etc, Iâ€™ve spent a few days and nights out there through work lunches and after work socials.

Itâ€™s a shame then that Hatch is closing soon after 6 years at short notice (September 30th), the land sold/leased to a company (Stack) who plans a similar operation but without any guarantees to the current tenants or permanent staff of continuation or redeployment. The *MENÂ *reports that these people have only a monthâ€™s notice find new premises or new jobs, though they will receive priority during recruitment, there are no certainties. Sacha Lord has offered all those affected at Hatch a job at the Warehouse Project when it returns for its new season.
items.content_text:
Earlier this week I came across a modernist [illustration by Bo Lundberg](https://www.juniqe.co.uk/manchester-17-premium-poster-portrait-5364428.html) of Hatch with the Mancunian Way in the background. A shipping container-style market of independent eateries, coffee shops, bars, breweries, clothes shops, florists etc, Iâ€™ve spent a few days and nights out there through work lunches and after work socials. 

![](https://notes.gazshaw.co.uk/uploads/2023/6786de2a-91d7-4b7c-b486-c1cff4bbc757.jpeg)

Itâ€™s a shame then that Hatch is closing soon after 6 years at short notice (September 30th), the land sold/leased to a company (Stack) who plans a similar operation but without any guarantees to the current tenants or permanent staff of continuation or redeployment. The *MENÂ *reports that these people have only a monthâ€™s notice find new premises or new jobs, though they will receive priority during recruitment, there are no certainties. Sacha Lord has [offered all those affected at Hatch a job at the Warehouse Project](https://x.com/sacha_lord/status/1697593221184934231?s=46&t=6DeAGxZgcWiqQIAYcmmefg) when it returns for its new season.

items.title: We (possibly) donâ€™t need another Twitter
items.content_html:
Cal Newport blogs that we donâ€™t need another Twitter. I suppose he would say that not being a fan of attention-sapping devices. While Twitter became too big to be a nice, sane, twee, â€˜global conversation platformâ€™â€”and I generally agree that in the broadest sense Twitter had long been a home for toxic babbleâ€”there are use cases for good that may be left unfulfilled if the Twitter we knew ceases to be. For example, academic Twitter.

Mark Carrigan asks where academics will turn:

My broader concern is that universities are still pushingâ€¦ that every upwardly mobile ambitious academic needs to be highly visible on the dominant platform and be seen engaging on a regular basis. That was always bad advice, and, now, it is becoming counterproductive and, in some cases, dangerous, adviceâ€¦

Twitter facilitated a social infrastructure for academic life in which a limited few with a big social media footprint were able to leverage it to advantage in their academic career, with greater visibility for their publications, a wide network and lots of opportunities. As that breaks down, our academic communities need to get much better at facilitating other modes of engagement so that we are never again so reliant on a big corporate platformâ€¦

Iâ€™m increasingly convinced there isnâ€™t going to be one single Twitter alternative because the marketplace of Twitter alternatives is so crowded. For an individual academic, the key is to experiment with a platform to get a sense of whether it worksâ€¦

Gina Sipley argues that even if Twitter manages to stabilise and maintain the trust of academics it will still block one the main benefitsâ€”leveraging their biggest audience, lurkers:

Lurking is a lucrative form of social media participation for platforms, if the lurker is logged in and the micrometrics of their reading history can be tracked. Content creators and influencers want their tweets to be seen by the largest possible audience; putting restrictions on lurking benefits the platform, not the creatorâ€¦

Twitter Blue subscribers have access to a reader mode, which declutters the reading experience by displaying fewer ads. By enhancing the reading experience one can more leisurely lurk. However, the cost of subscribing to Twitter Blue reinforces the privileged position of the lurker. Without a subscription to Twitter Blue, lurking is a less enjoyable experienceâ€¦ but its price has jumped to $8 per month. This is a prohibitive price point for academics, many of whom are underemployedâ€¦

Without a Twitter Blue subscription, a current Twitter account holder could only read 600 posts per day; a new Twitter account holder could only read 300. That number has recently been lifted to 1,000 posts for current account holders, but a limit of any kind creates a geography of exclusion to lurking. Attempting to read more than the daily allotted posts, will result in a locked account. Although Musk asserts that the restrictions are temporary, no end date has yet to be announced.

Further, TweetDeck, a tool that made it easy to manage and read the tweets of multiple accounts, is no longer a free service and can only be accessed through what is now called X-premium. Twitterâ€™s API library is also no longer open accessâ€¦ The current monthly cost of being a professional lurker: $1,000â€“$42,000.

Twitter and Facebook also became the first port of call for finding out what was happening right now on a particular topic. Whether that was globally on a breaking news story or hyper-locally to see why those fireworks were going off at 9.50pm on a Tuesday night in September. Today, whether by design or lack of resource, search on both platforms is borked to such a degree that itâ€™s useless. Hashtags, for following topics, conferences and such still work, but the participants and the audience is fracturing.

In terms of getting the message out there, there is something to be said for large platforms that dominate their market. For example, twenty years ago, if you lived in Greater Manchester and wanted a new job, you would buy Thursdayâ€™s Manchester Evening News. It was the outlet for advertising and finding job vacancies. The search engines and web aggregators of today are plenty but arenâ€™t as useful, taking up more time and energy to sifter. Similarly, Twitter was the every personâ€™s PR outlet.

So, where to turn? Facebook is too personal. Instagram and TikTok donâ€™t work in the same way; few can record and cut a hot take in one minute, never mind wanting to watch one. Some have turned to Linkedin, but the live element doesnâ€™t really work there either. There is also an inauthenticity to using LinkedIn where we are projections of our professional image rather than our rounded selves. Whatsapp groups and conversations may be an outlet for the live discussion, say at a conference for example, but itâ€™s hardly open to the web.

Metaâ€™s Threads appears to have legs. Although itâ€™s intrinsically linked to Instagram, people seem to like the way its going for itâ€™s more ephemeral, fun nature. Like the early days of Twitter, perhaps, but unlike the early days of Twitter, it does not have a text search function (yet) and does not have an API allowing for third-party clients (yet) like Tweetbot and Twitterific way back when. There are also the usual Meta issues with data collection, oh and those terms and conditions, which most will let slide if Threads hangs around for the long term. Although beyond grabbing market share from Twitter or even hobbling Muskâ€™s X to the extent that it never bounces back, will Meta keep Threads as an ongoing concern, particularly if they canâ€™t monetise it? Will Threads become so big that it inevitably morphs into the more derided, toxic, pre-Musk Twitter? And if you feel this may happen, is it worth investing time into building a profile on there?

Bluesky and Mastodon are in the peloton for taking the bluebird jersey. Bluesky is dragging its feet a little though maybe playing the long game. Mastodon is arguably best placed to be what Twitter was when it was good. Decentralised and open source, Mastodon offers the promise to be whatever you want it to be. Sadly, the infrastructure for Mastodon around instancesâ€”all of which have their own ownerships, hosting bills and posting rulesâ€”will be confusing to many, and the user experience for finding people and content from those you donâ€™t follow just isnâ€™t there yet, and may never be because of that infrastructure. If you join a niche instance and post on there as you have been doing on Twitter, you may get short shrift from that instanceâ€™s administrator. Perhaps you didnâ€™t refer to the correct source, or what you have posted is self-promotory to the extent that it breaks those rules. Mastodon is not yet built for, and may never be, for the mass.

That said, Mastodon is my current fave. As it utilises the decentralised protocol ActivityPub, it offers a route towards services that cover most of the aspects that made old Twitter good, that aggregate content from wherever it is publishedâ€”whether from websites, blogs, social networksâ€”that are also platform agnostic, thus negating that need for big corporate platforms and, perhaps, why we possibly donâ€™t need another Twitter in the long term. Though itâ€™s arguably closer to a pipe dream. Anyone for RSS?
items.content_text:
Cal Newport blogs that [we donâ€™t need another Twitter](https://calnewport.com/we-dont-need-a-new-twitter/). I suppose he would say that not being a fan of attention-sapping devices. While Twitter became too big to be a nice, sane, twee, â€˜global conversation platformâ€™â€”and I generally agree that in the broadest sense Twitter had long been a home for toxic babbleâ€”there are use cases for good that may be left unfulfilled if the Twitter we knew ceases to be. For example, academic Twitter.

[Mark Carrigan](https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/highereducation/2023/07/27/where-now-for-academics-on-social-media-post-twitter/) asks where academics will turn:

>My broader concern is that universities are still pushingâ€¦ that every upwardly mobile ambitious academic needs to be highly visible on the dominant platform and be seen engaging on a regular basis. That was always bad advice, and, now, it is becoming counterproductive and, in some cases, dangerous, adviceâ€¦
>
>Twitter facilitated a social infrastructure for academic life in which a limited few with a big social media footprint were able to leverage it to advantage in their academic career, with greater visibility for their publications, a wide network and lots of opportunities. As that breaks down, our academic communities need to get much better at facilitating other modes of engagement so that we are never again so reliant on a big corporate platformâ€¦
>
>Iâ€™m increasingly convinced there isnâ€™t going to be one single Twitter alternative because the marketplace of Twitter alternatives is so crowded. For an individual academic, the key is to experiment with a platform to get a sense of whether it worksâ€¦

[Gina Sipley](https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/impactofsocialsciences/2023/08/18/building-an-alternative-to-academic-twitter-relies-on-centring-the-experiences-of-lurkers/) argues that even if Twitter manages to stabilise and maintain the trust of academics it will still block one the main benefitsâ€”leveraging their biggest audience, lurkers:

>Lurking is a lucrative form of social media participation for platforms, if the lurker is logged in and the micrometrics of their reading history can be tracked. Content creators and influencers want their tweets to be seen by the largest possible audience; putting restrictions on lurking benefits the platform, not the creatorâ€¦
> 
>Twitter Blue subscribers have access to a reader mode, which declutters the reading experience by displaying fewer ads. By enhancing the reading experience one can more leisurely lurk. However, the cost of subscribing to Twitter Blue reinforces the privileged position of the lurker. Without a subscription to Twitter Blue, lurking is a less enjoyable experienceâ€¦ but its price has jumped to $8 per month. This is a prohibitive price point for academics, many of whom are underemployedâ€¦
>
>Without a Twitter Blue subscription, a current Twitter account holder could only read 600 posts per day; a new Twitter account holder could only read 300. That number has recently been lifted to 1,000 posts for current account holders, but a limit of any kind creates a geography of exclusion to lurking. Attempting to read more than the daily allotted posts, will result in a locked account. Although Musk asserts that the restrictions are temporary, no end date has yet to be announced.
>
>Further, TweetDeck, a tool that made it easy to manage and read the tweets of multiple accounts, is no longer a free service and can only be accessed through what is now called X-premium. Twitterâ€™s API library is also no longer open accessâ€¦ The current monthly cost of being a professional lurker: $1,000â€“$42,000.

Twitter and Facebook also became the first port of call for finding out what was happening right now on a particular topic. Whether that was globally on a breaking news story or hyper-locally to see why those fireworks were going off at 9.50pm on a Tuesday night in September. Today, whether by design or lack of resource, search on both platforms is borked to such a degree that itâ€™s useless. Hashtags, for following topics, conferences and such still work, but the participants and the audience is fracturing.

In terms of getting the message out there, there is something to be said for large platforms that dominate their market. For example, twenty years ago, if you lived in Greater Manchester and wanted a new job, you would buy Thursdayâ€™s *Manchester Evening News*. It was *the* outlet for advertising and finding job vacancies. The search engines and web aggregators of today are plenty but arenâ€™t as useful, taking up more time and energy to sifter. Similarly, Twitter was *the* every personâ€™s PR outlet.

So, where to turn? Facebook is too personal. Instagram and TikTok donâ€™t work in the same way; few can record and cut a hot take in one minute, never mind wanting to watch one. Some have turned to Linkedin, but the live element doesnâ€™t really work there either. There is also an inauthenticity to using LinkedIn where we are projections of our professional image rather than our rounded selves. Whatsapp groups and conversations may be an outlet for the live discussion, say at a conference for example, but itâ€™s hardly open to the web.

Metaâ€™s Threads appears to have legs. Although itâ€™s intrinsically linked to Instagram, people seem to like the way its going for itâ€™s more ephemeral, fun nature. Like the early days of Twitter, perhaps, but unlike the early days of Twitter, it does not have a text search function (yet) and does not have an API allowing for third-party clients (yet) like Tweetbot and Twitterific way back when. There are also the usual Meta issues with data collection, oh and those terms and conditions, which most will let slide if Threads hangs around for the long term. Although beyond grabbing market share from Twitter or even hobbling Muskâ€™s X to the extent that it never bounces back, will Meta keep Threads as an ongoing concern, particularly if they canâ€™t monetise it? Will Threads become so big that it inevitably morphs into the more derided, toxic, pre-Musk Twitter? And if you feel this may happen, is it worth investing time into building a profile on there?

Bluesky and Mastodon are in the peloton for taking the bluebird jersey. Bluesky is dragging its feet a little though maybe playing the long game. Mastodon is arguably best placed to be what Twitter was when it was good. Decentralised and open source, Mastodon offers the promise to be whatever you want it to be. Sadly, the infrastructure for Mastodon around instancesâ€”all of which have their own ownerships, hosting bills and posting rulesâ€”will be confusing to many, and the user experience for finding people and content from those you donâ€™t follow just isnâ€™t there yet, and may never be because of that infrastructure. If you join a niche instance and post on there as you have been doing on Twitter, you may get short shrift from that instanceâ€™s administrator. Perhaps you didnâ€™t refer to the correct source, or what you have posted is self-promotory to the extent that it breaks those rules. Mastodon is not yet built for, and may never be, for the mass. 

That said, Mastodon is my current fave. As it utilises the decentralised protocol ActivityPub, it offers a route towards services that cover most of the aspects that made old Twitter good, that aggregate content from wherever it is publishedâ€”whether from websites, blogs, social networksâ€”that are also platform agnostic, thus negating that need for big corporate platforms and, perhaps, why we possibly donâ€™t need another Twitter in the long term. Though itâ€™s arguably closer to a pipe dream. Anyone for RSS?

items.title: Cigarettes and SIN
items.content_html:
Keith Houston has published a â€˜calculator of the dayâ€™ for a week or so now in promotion of his new book, EmÂ­pire of the Sum: The Rise and Reign of the Pocket CalÂ­cuÂ­lator. This particular one is a belter and very much a sign of the times: the 1981 CaÂ­sio QL-10 CalÂ­cuÂ­lighter. Thatâ€™s right, a calculator with a cigarette lighter built-in. Old school cool if totally impractical and archaic by 21st century standards.

ğŸ“· CC BY-SA 2.0 by Vicente Zorilla Palau.

Keith makes an interesting point about this model and Casio:

Had this been any other calÂ­cuÂ­lator comÂ­pany, it would be have been enÂ­tirely posÂ­sible to deÂ­ride the QL-10 as â€™80s exÂ­cess gone mad. But CaÂ­sio alone could claim method in its madÂ­ness, beÂ­cause it had got starÂ­ted not with elecÂ­tronic inÂ­struÂ­ments, as had HewÂ­lett-PackÂ­ard; nor with geoÂ­physÂ­ical surÂ­veyÂ­ing equipÂ­ment, like Texas InÂ­struÂ­ments; nor camÂ­eras, like Canon; but rather, with the humble yuÂ­biwa ciÂ­garÂ­ette holder. For CaÂ­sio, the QL-10 was a homeÂ­comÂ­ing.
items.content_text:
Keith Houston has published a â€˜calculator of the dayâ€™ for a week or so now in promotion of his new book, *[EmÂ­pire of the Sum: The Rise and Reign of the Pocket CalÂ­cuÂ­lator](https://shadycharacters.co.uk/books/empire-of-the-sum/ "EmÂ­pire of the Sum: The Rise and Reign of the Pocket CalÂ­cuÂ­lator")*. This particular one is a belter and very much a sign of the times: the 1981 CaÂ­sio QL-10 CalÂ­cuÂ­lighter. Thatâ€™s right, a calculator with a cigarette lighter built-in. Old school cool if totally impractical and archaic by 21st century standards.

![QL-10 CalÂ­cuÂ­lighter](https://notes.gazshaw.co.uk/uploads/2023/c8b48c5d2b.jpg)

ğŸ“· [CC BY-SA 2.0](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0/) by [Vicente Zorilla Palau](https://www.flickr.com/photos/44337451@N00/5677495372/).

Keith [makes an interesting point](https://shadycharacters.co.uk/2023/08/ql-10/) about this model and Casio:

> Had this been any other calÂ­cuÂ­lator comÂ­pany, it would be have been enÂ­tirely posÂ­sible to deÂ­ride the QL-10 as â€™80s exÂ­cess gone mad. But CaÂ­sio alone could claim method in its madÂ­ness, beÂ­cause it had got starÂ­ted not with elecÂ­tronic inÂ­struÂ­ments, as had HewÂ­lett-PackÂ­ard; nor with geoÂ­physÂ­ical surÂ­veyÂ­ing equipÂ­ment, like Texas InÂ­struÂ­ments; nor camÂ­eras, like Canon; but rather, with the humble *yuÂ­biwa* ciÂ­garÂ­ette holder. For CaÂ­sio, the QL-10 was a homeÂ­comÂ­ing.

items.content_html:
Oh the levels of irony of being told we had to sit down on our plastic picnic seats in ordered rows and werenâ€™t allowed to dance by jobsworth minimum wage stewards while the band were playing (We Donâ€™t Need This) Fascist Groove Thang.

items.content_html: Anytime Heat or Manhunter pops up during a channel hop, it turns a potential early night into an inevitable early morning. Michael Mannâ€™s new film, 30 years in the making, is called Ferrari. I suppose you can guess what it might be about. Mann, (Adam) Driver and (Penelope) Cruz. Yes please.
items.content_text: Anytime *Heat* or *Manhunter* pops up during a channel hop, it turns a potential early night into an inevitable early morning. I suppose you can guess what it might be about. Mann, (Adam) Driver and (Penelope) Cruz. Yes please.

items.title: Train surfing
items.content_html: Now and again a social media trend emerges that worries or at least concerns. Not necessarily parents, but the issue compounds for them. Four people, all teenagers, have died this year â€˜surfingâ€™ trains on the New York Subway. Riding outside trains, usually on-top of carriages, is nothing new as Curbed points out. Rather it has been revived into the zeitgeist by â€˜surfersâ€™ posting their adventures on TikTok.
items.content_text: Now and again a social media trend emerges that worries or at least concerns. Not necessarily parents, but the issue compounds for them. Four people, all teenagers, have died this year â€˜surfingâ€™ trains on the New York Subway. Riding outside trains, usually on-top of carriages, is nothing new as [*Curbed* points out](https://www.curbed.com/2023/08/subway-surfing-teenagers-social-media-quitting-mta.html). Rather it has been revived into the zeitgeist by â€˜surfersâ€™ posting their adventures on TikTok.

items.content_html: Ikea is moving into the former Top Shop space on Oxford Street, London. Ben Terrett shows they have turned the front of the building into a huge Ikea blue bag. Smart.
items.content_text: Ikea is moving into the former Top Shop space on Oxford Street, London. [Ben Terrett](https://noisydecentgraphics.typepad.com/design/2023/08/most-scaffolding-in-a-special-build-award.html) shows they have turned the front of the building into a huge Ikea blue bag. Smart.

items.title: Washout moan
items.content_html: Four seasons in one day strikes again! Sure you have to expect this in Manchester, particularly if rain isnâ€™t forecast, and there’s the local maxim of just buying a decent waterproof coat and getting on with it. But who wants to walk around in a Berghaus when itâ€™s 20â„ƒ? (And arenâ€™t in a Britpop tribute band.) Yes, the weather was lovely before July, butâ€”and you call it a hangover from schooldaysâ€”Â the weather in July and August defines the summer, nay the sunny season for the year. And this year has been a washout. Hereâ€™s to a balmy October.
items.content_text: Four seasons in one day strikes again! Sure you have to expect this in Manchester, particularly if rain isnâ€™t forecast, and there's the local maxim of just buying a decent waterproof coat and getting on with it. But who wants to walk around in a Berghaus when itâ€™s 20â„ƒ? (And arenâ€™t in a Britpop tribute band.) Yes, the weather was lovely before July, butâ€”and you call it a hangover from schooldaysâ€”Â the weather in July and August defines the summer, nay the sunny season for the year. And this year has been a washout. Hereâ€™s to a balmy October.

items.title: The real Kananga
items.content_html: The stunt in Live and Let Die where James Bond clears a crocodile-infested lake by using said crocodiles as stepping stones was done by Ross Kananga. It took this crocodile farm owner three failed attempts before the good 4th take. Remarkable, particularly when you consider Kananga fatherâ€™s was killed by one of those crocodiles. Surely Kanangaâ€™s name was taken for the villainâ€™s Mr Big a.k.a Dr Kananga. (Via All the Right Movies)
items.content_text: The stunt in *Live and Let Die* where James Bond clears a crocodile-infested lake by using said crocodiles as stepping stones was done by Ross Kananga. It took this crocodile farm owner three failed attempts before the good 4th take. Remarkable, particularly when you consider Kananga fatherâ€™s was killed by one of those crocodiles. Surely Kanangaâ€™s name was taken for the villainâ€™s Mr Big a.k.a Dr Kananga. (Via [All the Right Movies](https://twitter.com/ATRightMovies/status/1691902651620012039)) {{< youtube bb1c1aMcFAo >}}

items.title: Raleigh Vektar
items.content_html: Retro Electro Workshop is like The Repair Shop solely for nostalgic tech nerds but with the sentimentality dialed down. I recorded one episode because I found out serendipitously that it covered the repair of a Commodore 64 and a Spectrum 48k. But what the episode also covered was an old Raleigh Vektar, a BMX bike with digital displays, a speedometer and a radio; something I had completely forgotten about from my childhood. I never had one but someone from school did, and for a brief period it was a wonderful thing. The closest a kid could get to becoming Street Hawk.
items.content_text: *Retro Electro Workshop* is like *The Repair Shop* solely for nostalgic tech nerds but with the sentimentality dialed down. I recorded one episode because I found out serendipitously that it covered the repair of a Commodore 64 and a Spectrum 48k. But what the episode also covered was an old [Raleigh Vektar](https://bmxmuseum.com/bikes/raleigh/38402), a BMX bike with digital displays, a speedometer and a radio; something I had completely forgotten about from my childhood. I never had one but someone from school did, and for a brief period it was a wonderful thing. The closest a kid could get to becoming Street Hawk.

items.content_html: Weâ€™re halfway through the second series of The Bear. Not quite as chaotic as the first but it has its fair share of chaos. Itâ€™s the little moments and the details in this one. The episode in Copenhagen was lovely.

items.content_text: Oh and [those toy-like cars](https://notes.gazshaw.co.uk/2023/08/16/zermatt-switzerland-does.html) in Zermatt are all handmade and cost the equivalent of Â£125,000, but have a service life of 30â€“50 years!

items.content_html: Zermatt, Switzerland does not allow private vehicles. You can catch the train in from the next town or walk it there. Within the boundary you can use public transport. The few cars allowed are utilitarian, made in the town and run on batteries like milk floats (via @Kottke).
items.content_text: Zermatt, Switzerland [does not allow private vehicles](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R2oD1ZHNMFE). You can catch the train in from the next town or walk it there. Within the boundary you can use public transport. The few cars allowed are utilitarian, made in the town and run on batteries like milk floats (via [@Kottke](https://botsin.space/@kottke)). {{< youtube R2oD1ZHNMFE >}}

items.content_html: Looking for a mnemonic for hyperlinks in Markdown as I keep getting the order wrong. [square peg](round hole) by David Winterbottom is a good start but it doesnâ€™t indicate within which the title and the URL go. What about [square cuffs](round cufflinks)?
items.content_text: Looking for a mnemonic for hyperlinks in Markdown as I keep getting the order wrong. `[square peg](round hole)` by [David Winterbottom](https://twitter.com/codeinthehole/status/656917944199454722?lang=en) is a good start but it doesnâ€™t indicate within which the title and the URL go. What about `[square cuffs](round cufflinks)`?

items.title: KSI, Mr Beast; on the cover of an ice cold Feast
items.content_html:
W. David Marx asks: â€˜In the mid-1970s, the Sex Pistols only took two years to move up from squalid London squats to the top of the British pop charts. Why hasn’t a decade been enough time for DIY online video creators to turn their view counts into mainstream stardom?â€™

Marx posits a number of conclusions as to why few if any social media sensations can be called mainstream celebrities. I’m not entirely sold on them, but what he says here rings true and remains a conundrum:

Weâ€™re now at least 15 years into the dominance of online video within youth culture. In the early 2010s, surveys started to find that teenagers were much more interested in YouTube creators than legacy media stars. At the time, it seemed plausible that youth would carry these preferences into their 20s and elevate their favorite creators. That didnâ€™t happen.

The acid test: could the names of social mediaâ€™s most watched replace those in Madonnaâ€™s â€˜Vogueâ€™ and echo through the decades?
items.content_text:
W. David Marx [asks](https://culture.ghost.io/why-havent-internet-creators-become-superstars): â€˜In the mid-1970s, the Sex Pistols only took two years to move up from squalid London squats to the top of the British pop charts. Why hasn't a decade been enough time for DIY online video creators to turn their view counts into mainstream stardom?â€™ 

Marx posits a number of conclusions as to why few if any social media sensations can be called mainstream celebrities. I'm not entirely sold on them, but what he says here rings true and remains a conundrum:

> Weâ€™re now at least 15 years into the dominance of online video within youth culture. In the early 2010s, surveys started to find that teenagers were much more interested in YouTube creators than legacy media stars. At the time, it seemed plausible that youth would carry these preferences into their 20s and elevate their favorite creators. That didnâ€™t happen.

The acid test: could the names of social mediaâ€™s most watched replace those in Madonnaâ€™s â€˜Vogueâ€™ and echo through the decades?

items.title: Sounds of Space
items.content_html: Hear the â€˜music of the Universeâ€™ at Sounds of Space. Mercury is my favourite, which sounds like the aftermath of a gruesome murder in an 80s video nasty, or if you prefer, the beginning of a Jeff Mills-type banger. Jupiter sounds like a lovely, peaceful stroll in a park, which is about as far removed as the reality of Jupiter.
items.content_text: Hear the â€˜music of the Universeâ€™ at [Sounds of Space](https://students.tools/sounds-of-space). Mercury is my favourite, which sounds like the aftermath of a gruesome murder in an 80s video nasty, or if you prefer, the beginning of a Jeff Mills-type banger. Jupiter sounds like a lovely, peaceful stroll in a park, which is about as far removed as the reality of Jupiter.

items.title: Oppenheimer the movie
items.content_html: I end to agree with Craig Mod and Khoi on Oppenheimer. I thought it tried to cram too many characters in early doors. Keeping tabs on all the names was an effort. I also donâ€™t think the A Few Good Men style grillings added much to the film. If anything it dragged it out (to 3 hours, plus the 30 minutes of adverts you have to sit through). While it was a valiant effort, I donâ€™t think I could recommend Oppenheimer to everyone.
items.content_text: I end to agree with [Craig Mod](https://craigmod.com/roden/082) and [Khoi](https://www.subtraction.com/2023/08/13/movies-watched-july-2023) on *Oppenheimer*. I thought it tried to cram too many characters in early doors. Keeping tabs on all the names was an effort. I also donâ€™t think the *A Few Good Men* style grillings added much to the film. If anything it dragged it out (to 3 hours, plus the 30 minutes of adverts you have to sit through). While it was a valiant effort, I donâ€™t think I could recommend *Oppenheimer* to everyone.

items.content_html: Watched The Take, action film set in France starting Idris Elba and Richard Madden. Not bad.
items.content_text: Watched The Take, action film set in France starting Idris Elba and Richard Madden. Not bad.

items.content_html: Earlier I was on Ebay placing a new listing. Itâ€™s one of those things you just want done, so having AI suggest a description based on the itemâ€™s particulars is a promising and valid use case. So I clicked OK. The result read like something out of a J. Peterman catalogue. Pass. Needs more work.

items.title: Father and son
items.content_html:
Thereâ€™s been some chatter on social regarding the sub 60,000 crowd at Wembley for the Challenge Cup final between Leigh and Hull KR. I thought they did alright to get circa. 60,000. Iâ€™m not sure any combination of teams would draw more than 75,000 in the current climate.

Congrats to Leigh in their first Challenge Cup victory in 50-odd years. Regardless of how you feel about them, this touching scene where coach and star playerâ€”father and sonâ€”embrace after the final hooter is gold.

Bar Ivan and Nathan Cleary at Penrith in the last couple of NRL Grand Finals, any more notable father and son victories?
items.content_text:
Thereâ€™s been some chatter on social regarding the sub 60,000 crowd at Wembley for the Challenge Cup final between Leigh and Hull KR. I thought they did alright to get circa. 60,000. Iâ€™m not sure any combination of teams would draw more than 75,000 in the current climate. 

Congrats to Leigh in their first Challenge Cup victory in 50-odd years. Regardless of how you feel about them, this touching scene where coach and star playerâ€”father and sonâ€”embrace after the final hooter is gold. 

![](https://notes.gazshaw.co.uk/uploads/2023/adrian-and-lachlan-lam.png)

Bar Ivan and Nathan Cleary at Penrith in the last couple of NRL Grand Finals, any more notable father and son victories?

items.title: Imagine That! & New Brighton â€“ 8.8.2023
items.content_html:
We decided to cram the early part of the week with day trips before Joeâ€™s Achilles operation on Thursday. Merseyside was the destination starting with Imagine That!, a kind of mix between the best bits of The Little Lancashire Village and Eureka!. Four zones with 30â€“40ish minutes in each zone. Anywhere that serves up free samples of ice cream cooled with dry ice is well worth a visit.

Then, having previously mentioned my work visit to New Brighton, we took another visit, but with much better weather this time around. A small beach, another ice cream, a walk down the promenade and staying for our tea. We enjoyed it.

I peeled away for 20 minutes or so to take some photos of the street art which adorns several dwellings around the high street.
items.content_text:
We decided to cram the early part of the week with day trips before Joeâ€™s Achilles operation on Thursday. Merseyside was the destination starting with [Imagine That!](https://imaginethat.org.uk "Imagine That!"), a kind of mix between the best bits of [The Little Lancashire Village](https://www.thelittlelancashirevillage.co.uk "The Little Lancashire Village") and [Eureka!](https://www.eureka.org.uk "Eureka!"). Four zones with 30â€“40ish minutes in each zone. Anywhere that serves up free samples of ice cream cooled with dry ice is well worth a visit.

![](https://notes.gazshaw.co.uk/uploads/2023/imagine-that-1.jpg)

![](https://notes.gazshaw.co.uk/uploads/2023/imagine-that-2.jpg)

Then, having previously mentioned my work visit to New Brighton, we took another visit, but with much better weather this time around. A small beach, another ice cream, a walk down the promenade and staying for our tea. We enjoyed it. 

![](https://notes.gazshaw.co.uk/uploads/2023/new-brighton-lighthouse.jpg)

![](https://notes.gazshaw.co.uk/uploads/2023/new-brighton.jpg)

![](https://notes.gazshaw.co.uk/uploads/2023/new-brighton-pigeon.jpg)

![](https://notes.gazshaw.co.uk/uploads/2023/new-brighton-benches.jpg)

![](https://notes.gazshaw.co.uk/uploads/2023/new-brighton-arcade.jpg)

![](https://notes.gazshaw.co.uk/uploads/2023/new-brighton-huts.jpg)

I peeled away for 20 minutes or so to take some photos of the street art which adorns several dwellings around the high street.

![](https://notes.gazshaw.co.uk/uploads/2023/new-brighton-street-art-1.jpg)

![](https://notes.gazshaw.co.uk/uploads/2023/new-brighton-street-art-2.jpg)

![](https://notes.gazshaw.co.uk/uploads/2023/new-brighton-street-art-3.jpg)
